category.term: 2361~Ashton Kutcher~Two and a Half Men~Chuck Lorre~Wally Schmidt
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
PASADENA, Calif. — Ashton Kutcher was in a pensive mood, quiet, soft-spoken and toying nervously with his wedding ring as he faced a room full of reporters Wednesday to promote Two and a Half Men, the chart-topping sitcom he joined at the season’s outset.

That’s not what caught everybody’s eye, though. What caught everybody’s eye was that he was clean-shaven with hair neatly trimmed, unlike the wild-haired, unshaven character he plays in Two and a Half Men.

Kutcher’s character, lovelorn high-tech billionaire Walden “Wally” Schmidt, was intentionally shaggy when he appeared in the season opener of Two and a Half Men, producer Chuck Lorre explained. Schmidt was recovering from a broken relationship; he was emotionally shattered, and the shaggy look was a way of showing, not telling.

That was then, this is now. When Two and a Half Men airs Monday with just its second new episode of the year, viewers will learn how and why Schmidt adopts the clean-shaven look. The story revolves around Schmidt’s recent love interest, played by Sophie Winkleman, trying to convince him to look less like a bum and more like a real man.

Back in the real world, Kutcher talked about Two and a Half Men has been a godsend for him personally. Now that the furor has died down over Sheen and whether Two and a Half Men would hold onto its audience without Sheen — four months later, the answer is an unequivocal “yes” — Kutcher can afford to kick back and relax.

The question now is, how much longer does he want to be a part of one of TV’s most-watched comedies? His contract is for a single season only.

“The question in the beginning was always, can we get the show off the ground, can we get it going,” Kutcher said. “There was never any long-term plan. The way it’s working, the show is outperforming where it was before I was here. People are responding to it. For me, having a show that people like and people want more of is going to dictate my decision. I have a couple of features in the summer, during the hiatus. And right now, that’s what I’m looking at it as: a hiatus.”

Kutcher quietly recalled a chance meeting with Robin Williams from Kutcher’s That ‘70s Show days, when That ‘70s Show was starting to draw attention and Kutcher was new to series television.

Williams, who made his name in the 1978-’82 sitcom Mork & Mindy, was appearing in a cameo role at the time.

“He said, ‘I’m so happy to be in a sitcom again,’” Kutcher recalled. “I never forgot that. So when I got this opportunity, I thought it was an unbelievable opportunity.”

Kutcher is not his character, he insisted — even though he plays a high-tech billionaire in the program and in real life he majored in biochemical engineering during his college years at the University of Iowa.

“Walden Schmidt reflects the views of the writers,” Kutcher said. “I play the character.”

Lorre, for his part, admitted the studio came close to shutting down Two and a Half Men following Sheen’s departure.

“Absolutely we considered it, because we never imagined we’d be in a position where we’d have to consider it any other way,” Lorre said. “It was impossible to think about it going forward.”

What changed?

“Ashton Kutcher. Listen, there was clearly an interest at the network in keeping the show going as long as possible. It just seemed like an impossible idea. At some point, though, we thought, why not try? What’s the harm in trying? If we fail, no one is going to crucify us for trying. And also, no one would be surprised. Everybody would be going, ‘What were they thinking? They failed.’ It’s just that it seemed like such a heartbreaking way to end the show. So we decided, let’s just do it; let’s see what we can do to keep it going. Yes, we had some false starts along the way. We had some false starts this fall. In retrospect, it was exactly the right thing to do.”

Lorre wishes only the best for Sheen, going forward. The two reputedly had a falling out during Two and a Half Men’s final days. Sheen, who is about to appear in a new FX comedy called Anger Management, told reporters this past weekend that he’s a changed man.

“I wish him well, I really do,” Lorre said. “I’m glad he’s sober, and I’m happy about how it’s worked out. I think it’s terrific.”

Two and a Half Men airs Mondays on CTV and CBS.

astrachan@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/astrachantv
